cases.note_text:
PATIENT: Margaret Chen || MRN: 8847291 || DOB: 04/22/1951 (73 y/o F)
Date: 12/03/2025 || Location: University Medical Center, Denver, CO
Attending: Dr. James Morrison, MD - Interventional Pulmonology

INDICATION: Patient with history of metastatic ovarian cancer s/p right PleurX catheter placement 4 months ago for recurrent malignant pleural effusion. Drainage has decreased to <50mL per session over the past 3 weeks. CT chest from 11/28/2025 demonstrates near-complete resolution of right pleural effusion with evidence of pleurodesis. Patient referred for IPC removal.

PROCEDURE: Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter (CPT 32552)

ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine (10mL)

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
The patient was positioned in the left lateral decubitus position. The right lateral chest wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The catheter exit site was identified. Local anesthesia was infiltrated along the subcutaneous tunnel tract. A small incision was made at the catheter exit site extending along the tunnel. The cuff was identified approximately 2cm from the exit site within the subcutaneous tissue. Using blunt dissection, the cuff was freed from surrounding tissue. The catheter was then withdrawn smoothly from the pleural space. The tract was inspected and hemostasis confirmed. The incision was closed with 3-0 nylon sutures. Sterile dressing applied.

FINDINGS:
- PleurX catheter removed intact with cuff
- No purulent drainage or signs of infection
- Minimal serous fluid at tract site
- Total catheter length: 28cm

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: <5mL

POST-PROCEDURE:
- Post-procedure CXR obtained - no pneumothorax
- Patient tolerated procedure well
- Discharge home with wound care instructions
- Follow-up in 2 weeks with repeat CXR

Dr. James Morrison, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: IPC removal due to spontaneous pleurodesis

code_rationales.32552: Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter (PleurX) with cuff.
Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff.

cases.note_text:
Pt: Robert Williams || MRN: 9923847 || DOB: 08/15/1948
Date: 12/05/2025 || Bronch Suite, Memorial Hospital, Phoenix, AZ
MD: Dr. Elena Rodriguez

Dx: CHF with hepatic hydrothorax s/p left PleurX 6 months ago, now with evidence of autopleurodesis

Procedure: Removal of tunneled pleural catheter, left

Consent obtained. Local anesthesia with lido 1% 15mL. Patient positioned right lateral decubitus. Exit site identified left posterior axillary line. Tunnel tract anesthetized. Incision made, cuff dissected free. Catheter withdrawn completely - 26cm total length. Wound closed 3-0 Vicryl. Tegaderm applied.

Catheter removed intact. No complications. Post-procedure US: no PTX, minimal residual fluid. Pt stable, discharged home.

F/U 1 week.

E. Rodriguez, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: IPC removal - autopleurodesis achieved

code_rationales.32552: Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter.
Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter from left hemithorax.

cases.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Susan Thompson
MRN: 1156723
DOB: 11/30/1962 (63F)
Date of Service: 12/07/2025
Location: Outpatient Procedure Center, Seattle, WA

Attending Physician: Dr. Michael Park, MD
Fellow: Dr. Amanda Liu, PGY-6

Pre-procedure Diagnosis: Right malignant pleural effusion secondary to NSCLC, s/p PleurX catheter placement 5 months ago with successful pleurodesis

Procedure Performed: Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter, right (32552)

Indication: Mrs. Thompson is a 63-year-old woman with stage IV NSCLC who underwent right PleurX catheter placement 5 months ago. Output has been <30mL for the past month. CT shows resolution of effusion with pleural symphysis.

Anesthesia: Local with 1% lidocaine 12mL

Procedure Details:
Timeout performed. Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. Right lateral chest prepped and draped. Exit site at 6th intercostal space, mid-axillary line identified. Local anesthesia infiltrated along tunnel tract. 2cm incision made at exit site. Blunt dissection to mobilize cuff. Gentle traction applied and catheter removed smoothly. Total length 27cm. Wound closed with 4-0 Monocryl. Steri-strips applied.

Complications: None
EBL: Minimal

Post-procedure: Bedside ultrasound - no pneumothorax, no significant pleural fluid.

Disposition: Discharged home
Follow-up: Oncology in 2 weeks, IP clinic PRN

Michael Park, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: IPC removal - successful pleurodesis in NSCLC patient

code_rationales.32552: Removal of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter.
Removal of right-sided indwelling tunneled pleural catheter.

cases.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: David Kim || MRN: 7734892 || DOB: 02/14/1955 (70M)
Date: 12/04/2025 || ICU, City General Hospital, Boston, MA
Attending: Dr. Sarah Johnson, MD

Indication: Large left pleural effusion in patient with decompensated heart failure causing respiratory distress. Urgent therapeutic thoracentesis requested.

Procedure: Thoracentesis, aspiration of pleural space, without imaging guidance (32554)

Anesthesia: Local - 1% lidocaine 8mL

Technique:
Patient positioned sitting upright at bedside. Physical exam demonstrated dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at left base extending to mid-scapula. Entry site selected at 8th intercostal space, posterior axillary line based on percussion findings. Skin prepped with chlorhexidine and draped. Local anesthesia infiltrated. 18G needle advanced over superior aspect of 9th rib while aspirating. Pleural fluid obtained at 4cm depth. Catheter advanced, needle withdrawn. 1800mL straw-colored fluid removed by gravity and gentle aspiration. Procedure stopped due to patient cough. Catheter removed. Pressure dressing applied.

Findings:
- Fluid appearance: Clear, straw-colored
- Volume removed: 1800mL

Complications: None

Post-procedure: Patient reports significant improvement in dyspnea. SpO2 improved from 88% to 95% on 2L NC.

Dr. Sarah Johnson, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Large left pleural effusion causing respiratory distress in decompensated CHF

code_rationales.32554: Thoracentesis performed without imaging guidance using physical exam landmarks.

cases.note_text:
Pt: Helen Martinez, 68F || MRN: 2298341
Date: 12/06/2025 || Floor 7 West, Riverside Hospital
MD: Dr. Kevin O'Brien

Dx: New right pleural effusion, etiology unknown. R/O malignancy vs parapneumonic.

Procedure: Diagnostic thoracentesis without imaging guidance (32554)

Physical exam: Dullness to percussion R base to angle of scapula. Decreased breath sounds. Entry site selected R 9th ICS, mid-scapular line.

Lido 1% 10mL local. 22G needle inserted, pleural fluid obtained at 3cm. 50mL bloody fluid withdrawn for diagnostic studies.

Fluid sent: cytology, cell count, protein, LDH, glucose, pH, cultures

Appearance: Serosanguinous
Volume: 50mL (diagnostic only)

No complications. Post-procedure exam: breath sounds unchanged, no crepitus.

Impression: Diagnostic thoracentesis completed. Await cytology and chemistry for Light's criteria.

K. O'Brien, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: New right pleural effusion of unknown etiology - diagnostic workup

code_rationales.32554: Diagnostic thoracentesis using physical examination landmarks without imaging guidance.

cases.note_text:
THORACENTESIS NOTE

Patient: William Foster
MRN: 3384756
DOB: 06/08/1960 (65 y/o Male)
Date: 12/08/2025
Location: Emergency Department, Valley Medical Center

Attending: Dr. Lisa Chang, Pulmonology

Clinical Indication: Patient presents with 2-week history of progressive dyspnea. Known history of cirrhosis (Child-Pugh B). Chest X-ray shows large right pleural effusion. Hepatic hydrothorax suspected.

Procedure: Thoracentesis, needle aspiration of pleural space, without imaging guidance (CPT 32554)

Technique:
Patient positioned sitting at edge of bed leaning forward. Physical examination confirmed dullness to percussion throughout right hemithorax. Skin marked at 7th intercostal space, posterior axillary line. Sterile prep. 1% lidocaine 10mL infiltrated. 18-gauge catheter-over-needle introduced, aspirating during advancement. Pleural space entered at 5cm depth. Catheter advanced, needle removed. Fluid drained by gravity. Total 2200mL removed over 25 minutes. Catheter removed.

Fluid Analysis:
- Appearance: Clear, straw-colored
- Volume: 2200mL

Complications: None. Patient denied chest pain, no cough during procedure.

Post-procedure Assessment:
- Breath sounds improved on right
- SpO2 97% on room air (pre-procedure 91%)

Impression: Successful therapeutic thoracentesis. Await SAAG for hepatic hydrothorax confirmation.

Dr. Lisa Chang, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Large right pleural effusion - suspected hepatic hydrothorax

code_rationales.32554: Thoracentesis performed using physical examination landmarks without imaging guidance. Large volume therapeutic drainage (2200mL).

cases.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Dorothy Adams || MRN: 4492817 || DOB: 03/22/1949 (76F)
Date: 12/03/2025 || Inpatient, Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago, IL
Attending: Dr. Richard Thompson, MD - Interventional Pulmonology

Indication: Recurrent symptomatic right malignant pleural effusion secondary to breast cancer. Patient has required 3 therapeutic thoracenteses in past 6 weeks. After multidisciplinary discussion, patient elected chemical pleurodesis over tunneled pleural catheter.

Procedure: Instillation of talc slurry via chest tube for pleurodesis (CPT 32560)

Pre-procedure: Small-bore chest tube (14Fr pigtail) was placed 2 days ago and has drained 2800mL total. CXR today shows near-complete drainage with lung re-expansion. Output now <100mL/24h.

Pleurodesis Procedure:
Patient positioned supine. Existing chest tube function confirmed with respiratory swing. Tube flushed with 20mL normal saline. Premixed talc slurry (4g talc in 50mL NS) warmed to body temperature. Slurry instilled via chest tube over 3 minutes. Tube flushed with 20mL NS. Tube clamped for 1 hour. Patient rotated to different positions every 15 minutes to distribute talc. After 1 hour, tube unclamped to suction at -20cmH2O.

Talc Dose: 4 grams

Complications: Patient experienced moderate pleuritic chest pain during instillation requiring IV morphine 4mg.

Post-procedure Plan:
- Continue chest tube to suction
- Monitor output
- CXR daily
- Remove tube when output <150mL/24h

Dr. Richard Thompson, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Recurrent symptomatic malignant pleural effusion - pleurodesis for palliation

code_rationales.32560: Instillation of talc slurry via chest tube for pleurodesis.
Instillation of talc slurry (4g) via existing chest tube for chemical pleurodesis.

cases.note_text:
Pt: George Patterson || MRN: 5573928 || DOB: 09/17/1952 (73M)
Date: 12/05/2025 || Inpatient 6 South, Metro General
MD: Dr. Angela White

Dx: Recurrent L pneumothorax s/p VATS wedge resection, persistent air leak

Procedure: Chemical pleurodesis with doxycycline via chest tube (32560)

Background: 73yo M with COPD and spontaneous L PTX. S/P VATS wedge resection 1 week ago with persistent air leak despite chest tube. Thoracic surgery requested chemical pleurodesis.

Procedure:
Existing 24Fr chest tube in place, functioning. Doxycycline 500mg dissolved in 50mL NS plus 10mL 1% lidocaine. Solution instilled via chest tube. Tube clamped x 2 hours with position changes q30 min. Tube returned to suction.

Agent: Doxycycline 500mg

Complications: Mild chest discomfort, managed with PO acetaminophen

Plan: Continue chest tube to suction, monitor air leak, repeat CXR tomorrow

A. White, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Persistent air leak post-VATS wedge resection for spontaneous pneumothorax

code_rationales.32560: Instillation of doxycycline solution via chest tube for chemical pleurodesis to treat persistent air leak.

cases.note_text:
PLEURODESIS PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Evelyn Richardson
MRN: 6684039
DOB: 12/01/1946 (79 y/o F)
Date of Service: 12/07/2025
Location: Inpatient Oncology, University Hospital, San Francisco

Attending: Dr. Brian Lee, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Fellow: Dr. Priya Patel, PGY-7

Indication: Mrs. Richardson is a 79-year-old woman with stage IV epithelial ovarian cancer with recurrent bilateral malignant pleural effusions. Decision made for left-sided talc pleurodesis.

Pre-procedure: Left 12Fr pigtail catheter placed yesterday. Total output 1600mL. Today's CXR shows adequate drainage with lung re-expansion.

Procedure Performed: Instillation of talc slurry via chest tube for chemical pleurodesis (CPT 32560)

Technique:
Consent verified. Patient positioned semi-recumbent. Pre-medication: morphine 4mg IV, ondansetron 4mg IV. Sterile talc 5g mixed with 100mL warmed NS. Slurry instilled slowly over 5 minutes via chest tube. Tube flushed with 20mL NS. Tube clamped. Patient rotated through positions every 15 minutes for total dwell time of 90 minutes. Tube then placed to water seal, then suction at -20cmH2O.

Agent: Talc 5g in 100mL NS (slurry)
Dwell Time: 90 minutes with position changes

Complications: Mild pleuritic discomfort. Temperature 37.8C 4 hours post-procedure.

Brian Lee, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Recurrent left malignant pleural effusion - chemical pleurodesis

code_rationales.32560: Instillation of talc slurry for pleurodesis.
Instillation of talc slurry (5g) via chest tube for chemical pleurodesis of left malignant pleural effusion.

category: +31632 - Bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy, additional lobe (add-on)

cases.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: James Wilson || MRN: 7795140 || DOB: 05/14/1958 (67M)
Date: 12/04/2025 || OR 3, Academic Medical Center, Philadelphia, PA
Attending: Dr. Nancy Chen, MD
Fellow: Dr. Steven Marks, PGY-6

Indication: Evaluation of bilateral lung nodules. CT shows 1.8cm RUL nodule and 1.2cm LUL nodule. Both PET-avid. Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsies of both lobes planned.

Procedure:
- Flexible bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (31624)
- Transbronchial lung biopsy, RUL - single lobe (31628)
- Transbronchial lung biopsy, LUL - additional lobe (+31632)
- Computer-assisted navigation (+31627)

Anesthesia: General anesthesia, 7.5 ETT

Procedure Details:
Bronchoscope introduced through ETT. Airways inspected - no endobronchial lesions. Navigation system (Ion) registered.

RUL Target (primary lesion):
Navigated to RUL apical segment. R-EBUS confirmed target. Forceps biopsies x6 obtained. Minimal bleeding.

LUL Target (additional lobe):
Navigated to LUL anterior segment. R-EBUS confirmed lesion. Forceps biopsies x5 obtained from second lobe. Mild bleeding, resolved.

BAL: 100mL NS to RUL, 60mL returned.

Fluoroscopy: 2.4 minutes total

Complications: None. Post-procedure CXR: No pneumothorax.

Nancy Chen, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Bilateral PET-avid lung nodules requiring tissue diagnosis

code_rationales.31628: Transbronchial lung biopsy of first lobe (RUL).
code_rationales.+31632: Transbronchial lung biopsy of additional lobe (LUL).

Procedures:
1. Bronchoscopy with BAL (31624)
2. Transbronchial lung biopsy, RUL - first lobe (31628)
3. Transbronchial lung biopsy, LUL - additional lobe (+31632)

Airways normal. No endobronchial lesions.

BAL: RUL, 120mL NS instilled, 70mL returned.

TBLB RUL (first lobe): 6 forceps biopsies. Adequate tissue. Mild bleeding.
TBLB LUL (additional lobe): 5 forceps biopsies. Minimal bleeding.

Fluoroscopy time: 2.1 minutes

Specimens to surgical pathology; BAL to cytology, fungal/AFB cultures, viral studies, PJP DFA.

Complications: None
Post-procedure CXR: No pneumothorax

Jennifer Adams, MD

cases.note_text:
EBUS BRONCHOSCOPY NOTE

Patient: Linda Chang || MRN: 1028374 || DOB: 08/19/1956 (69F)
Date: 12/03/2025 || OR 2, University Hospital, Los Angeles
Attending: Dr. William Harris, MD
Fellow: Dr. Samantha Lee, PGY-6

Indication: 69yo female with RUL adenocarcinoma. PET-CT shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy (stations 4R, 7, 4L) and separate LUL nodule. EBUS-TBNA for staging plus conventional TBNA of parenchymal targets.

Procedures:
- EBUS-TBNA, 3+ nodal stations (31653)
- Conventional TBNA from RUL mass - first lobe (31629)
- TBNA additional lobe - LUL nodule (+31633)

Anesthesia: General, 8.0 ETT

Procedure Details:
EBUS scope introduced. Systematic nodal sampling:
- Station 4R: 3 passes, ROSE positive for malignancy
- Station 7: 3 passes, ROSE positive for malignancy
- Station 4L: 3 passes, ROSE lymphocytes only

Conventional TBNA:
- RUL mass: 5 passes through RB1 using 22G needle (first parenchymal target)
- LUL nodule: 3 passes through LB3 using 22G needle (additional lobe)

Staging: Clinical N2 disease confirmed

William Harris, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Staging of RUL adenocarcinoma with mediastinal lymphadenopathy

code_rationales.31629: Conventional TBNA of RUL parenchymal mass - first lobe.

category: +31651 - Bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement, each additional bronchus (add-on)

cases.note_text:
BLVR VALVE PLACEMENT PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Harold Johnson || MRN: 4351628 || DOB: 11/03/1952 (73M)
Date: 12/04/2025 || Hybrid OR, National Jewish Health, Denver
Attending: Dr. Sarah Mitchell, MD

Indication: 73-year-old male with severe heterogeneous emphysema. FEV1 28% predicted. Target lobe: LUL. Pre-procedure Chartis CV-negative. Candidate for Zephyr valve BLVR.

Procedures:
1. Bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement, initial bronchus (31647)
2. Bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement, each additional bronchus x3 (+31651 x3)

Anesthesia: General, 8.0 ETT

Valve Placements:
1. LB1+2 (apicoposterior): Zephyr 5.5 valve, good seal (Initial)
2. LB3 (anterior): Zephyr 4.0 valve, seal confirmed (Add-on #1)
3. LB4 (superior lingula): Zephyr 5.5 valve, seal confirmed (Add-on #2)
4. LB5 (inferior lingula): Zephyr 4.0-LP valve, seal confirmed (Add-on #3)

Total valves placed: 4 Zephyr valves in LUL

Post-placement: All valves well-seated with complete lobar occlusion.

Complications: None

Sarah Mitchell, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Severe heterogeneous emphysema - BLVR candidate with CV-negative LUL

code_rationales.+31651 (x3): Three additional valves placed in LB3, LB4, and LB5.

category: 32557 - Pleural drainage with catheter insertion and imaging guidance

cases.note_text:
PLEURAL DRAINAGE PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Patricia Moore || MRN: 7684951 || DOB: 09/22/1958 (67F)
Date: 12/03/2025 || IR Suite, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore
Attending: Dr. Andrew Kim, MD

Indication: Complex parapneumonic effusion on right. CT shows loculated effusion. Requires image-guided drainage catheter placement.

Procedure: Percutaneous pleural drainage with insertion of indwelling catheter, with imaging guidance (CPT 32557)

Anesthesia: Local with 1% lidocaine 15mL + Moderate sedation (midazolam 2mg, fentanyl 50mcg)

Technique:
Patient positioned left lateral decubitus. Real-time ultrasound used. Entry site: right 7th ICS, posterior axillary line. Local anesthesia infiltrated under US guidance. 18G access needle advanced into fluid under continuous US. Guide wire placed. Tract dilated. 14Fr pigtail catheter placed and connected to drainage system.

Initial Drainage:
- Volume: 850mL
- Appearance: Turbid, yellow-brown

Post-procedure ultrasound: Catheter well-positioned, significant reduction in effusion, no PTX.

Complications: None

Andrew Kim, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Complex parapneumonic effusion requiring image-guided drainage

code_rationales.32557: Pleural drainage with percutaneous insertion of indwelling catheter under ultrasound guidance.

cases.note_text:
Pt: Richard Brown, 74M || MRN: 8795062
Date: 12/05/2025 || ICU, Metro Hospital
MD: Dr. Laura Martinez

Dx: Left empyema with respiratory failure

Procedure: Ultrasound-guided pleural drainage catheter placement (32557)

Urgent procedure. US showed large loculated L effusion. Entry: L 6th ICS, mid-axillary line. Lido 1% 12mL. Patient already intubated, propofol infusion.

Under real-time US, 18G needle into effusion, wire placed, dilated to 14Fr, pigtail catheter inserted.

Initial output: 1100mL frank pus. Sent for Gram stain, cultures.

Plan: Intrapleural tPA/DNase protocol. ID and thoracic surgery consulted.

L. Martinez, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Left empyema with respiratory failure

Patient: Nancy Wilson

DOB: 02/14/1962 (63 y/o F)
Date: 12/07/2025
Location: IR Suite, Mass General Hospital

Attending: Dr. Christopher Lee, MD
Fellow: Dr. Amy Chen, PGY-6

Indication: Large right malignant pleural effusion causing dyspnea. Therapeutic drainage with temporary catheter.

Procedure: Pleural drainage with insertion of indwelling catheter, with imaging guidance (CPT 32557)

Anesthesia: Local + moderate sedation (midazolam 3mg, fentanyl 75mcg)

Technique:
US-guided. Entry: Right 8th ICS, mid-axillary line. Under continuous US, access needle into effusion, guidewire placed, tract dilated, 12Fr multipurpose drainage catheter inserted.

Drainage:
- Total volume: 2400mL (stopped due to patient discomfort)
- Appearance: Serosanguinous

Pleural Pressures (manometry):
- Opening: -2 cmH2O
- At 2400mL: -22 cmH2O

Post-procedure: Marked reduction in effusion, no PTX.

Complications: Chest tightness during drainage, resolved after stopping.

Christopher Lee, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Large symptomatic malignant pleural effusion

category: 31638 - Bronchoscopy with revision or removal of stent

cases.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY - STENT REVISION NOTE

Patient: Frank Anderson || MRN: 1917284 || DOB: 04/18/1957 (68M)
Date: 12/03/2025 || OR 2, Cleveland Clinic
Attending: Dr. Thomas Chen, MD
Fellow: Dr. Jessica Kim, PGY-7

Indication: History of left mainstem bronchus adenocarcinoma s/p Ultraflex SEMS (covered) placed 6 months ago. Now with dyspnea. CT shows stent migration with proximal end protruding into distal trachea.

Procedure: Bronchoscopy with revision of bronchial stent (CPT 31638)

Anesthesia: General, jet ventilation via rigid bronchoscope

Procedure Details:
Rigid bronchoscopy performed. Findings: migrated covered SEMS with proximal end extending 1cm into distal trachea. Granulation tissue at proximal stent edge.

Stent Revision:
1. Granulation tissue debrided with rigid bronchoscope
2. Grasping forceps engaged proximal stent edge
3. Stent repositioned distally, back into left mainstem
4. Confirmed appropriate positioning with proximal edge just distal to carina
5. Flexible bronchoscope: stent lumen patent throughout

Post-revision: Stent patent, well-positioned. Airway patency restored.

Complications: None

Thomas Chen, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Migrated LMS stent causing airway obstruction - stent revision

code_rationales.31638: Bronchoscopy with revision of tracheal/bronchial stent. Migrated SEMS repositioned from distal trachea back into left mainstem bronchus.

cases.note_text:
Pt: Sandra Martinez, 71F || MRN: 2028395
Date: 12/05/2025 || Hybrid OR, Mount Sinai
MD: Dr. Robert Williams

Dx: Tracheal stenosis s/p Dumon silicone stent placement 2 years ago, now with granulation tissue causing obstruction

Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with stent removal (31638)

GA, rigid bronch. Dumon stent in mid-trachea with significant granulation tissue at both ends causing ~70% obstruction.

Procedure:
1. Granulation tissue ablated with APC at proximal and distal stent margins
2. Silicone stent grasped with alligator forceps
3. Stent removed intact through rigid bronchoscope
4. Trachea inspected - ~30% residual narrowing
5. Decision made to not replace stent given improvement

Stent removed: Dumon silicone, 14mm x 40mm, intact

Complications: Moderate bleeding from granulation tissue, controlled with APC.

R. Williams, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Granulation tissue obstructing tracheal stent - stent removal indicated

code_rationales.31638: Bronchoscopy with removal of tracheal stent (Dumon silicone). Includes granulation tissue ablation as part of stent removal.

cases.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY - STENT MANAGEMENT NOTE

Patient: William Taylor
MRN: 3139506
DOB: 08/30/1960 (65 y/o M)
Date: 12/08/2025
Location: OR 5, UCLA Medical Center

Attending: Dr. Michelle Park, MD
Fellow: Dr. Daniel Cho, PGY-6

Indication: Prior Y-stent placement for malignant airway obstruction from esophageal cancer. Now with mucus plugging and stent dysfunction.

Procedures:
1. Bronchoscopy with revision of tracheal/bronchial stent (31638)
2. Bronchoscopy with therapeutic aspiration (31645)

Anesthesia: General with jet ventilation

Procedure Details:
Rigid bronchoscopy. Y-stent (Dumon silicone) visualized in carina.

Findings:
- Significant mucus plugging within all three limbs
- Left limb: Near-complete obstruction
- Stent position appropriate, no migration
- Mild granulation tissue at distal edges

Intervention:
1. Therapeutic aspiration of copious thick mucus
2. Stent revision - forceps to remove adherent mucus plaques
3. Saline lavage through stent lumens
4. Granulation tissue cauterized with electrocautery
5. All three stent limbs now patent

Complications: None. Minimal bleeding from granulation cautery.

Michelle Park, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Y-stent mucus plugging causing airway obstruction - stent revision

code_rationales.31641: Cautery of granulation tissue (relief of stenosis); 31638 (revision) not supported as stent was not moved.

code_rationales.31638: Bronchoscopy with revision of tracheal/bronchial stent (Y-stent). Function restored without replacement.
code_rationales.31645: Therapeutic aspiration - copious thick mucus aspirated as distinct therapeutic service.
